alert.note: Alert for Grays Harbor; Thurston (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 02 at 3:49AM PST until March 03 at 10:11PM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Washington... Chehalis River Above Grand Mound affecting Grays Harbor and Thurston Counties. .No additional hydrologically significant rain is in the forecast for the next few days. The flood crest on the Chehalis will arrive at Grand Mound late Wednesday morning and at Porter Thursday morning. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Chehalis River Above Grand Mound. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow evening. * IMPACTS...At 142.5 feet, the Chehalis River in Thurston County will flood several roads in Independence Valley with swiftly moving water including SR-12 and James, Independence, Moon and Anderson Roads. Flood waters will cut off access to and from Chehalis Reservation and inundate nearby farm lands. Some residential structures may be threatened. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM PST Wednesday the stage was 142.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM PST Wednesday was 142.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 142.5 feet late this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 141.0 feet. - Flood History...No available flood history. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this afternoon at 1200 PM PST.
